explanation: The claim is not correct. The two lines “(void)lbus;” and “(void)dir;” are the standard idiom to indicate intentionally unused parameters and to suppress compiler warnings; they do not represent inadvertent or stale logic. Although an expression statement that casts a parameter to void has no runtime effect and its removal would not change program behaviour, MISRA’s intent for Rule 2.2 is to prohibit unintended dead/stale code that can mask mistakes — not to forbid explicit, documented no-op casts used to mark unused parameters. In practice this idiom is accepted as the correct way to document unused parameters (or else the parameter name can be omitted in the function prototype), so the agent A report of a Rule 2.2 violation is not correct for this code.
